awd_titl_txt: The unifying principles of biomolecular interactions as a predictive framework for biological mechanisms
awd_abstract_narration:
In this research project, the PI will develop unifying physical principles to study complex biological systems. These developments will build a foundation for extending single-molecule theory to molecular behavior in vivo. This program will train junior scientists to develop physics-based conceptual approaches that can encompass the complexity of living systems and to become leaders in this multi-disciplinary field. Building upon her successful development of the biological physics curriculum at UCSD, the PI will expand her efforts to integrate biological physics into curriculums beyond her home department. The PI will continue and expand upon her outreach initiatives in an effort to encourage and train scientists from a diverse range of academic and social backgrounds. The research and training activities in this project will benefit biotechnology industry.

The goal of this project is to establish the unifying physical principles that govern the functional dynamics of complex biomolecules. The project will provide a theoretical framework that can predict biological mechanisms as manifestations of the established unifying principles. Methods from nonequilibrium statistical physics will be developed and applied to formulate theoretical approaches that are sufficiently general to be applicable to a broad range of biomolecular systems and experimental techniques, and yet sufficiently simple to result in an analytical theory and generate experimentally testable predictions. This research program will extend the methodologies, developed in the PI's group and proven successful for small biomolecules, to more complex, large-scale multi-molecular assemblies and the conformational changes involved in their functional behavior.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on establishing the unifying physical principles that govern the functional dynamics of complex biological macromolecules. Methods from nonequilibrium statistical physics were developed and applied to formulate theoretical frameworks that are sufficiently general to be applicable to a broad range of systems yet sufficiently simple to result in analytically tractable theories and generate experimentally testable predictions.

 

A theory was developed that described, quantitatively, the remarkably efficient infection strategy of enveloped viruses. The theory reconciled the conflicting timescales of the viral infection and of the membrane fusion that is necessary for the release of viral genes. The predictive value of the theory was illustrated through application to experimental data on influenza virus infection. 

A molecular-scale mechanism was proposed and described that enables living systems to tailor their function to a new environment. The mechanism exploits the fact that conformational transitions in biomolecules ? which are the constituents of living systems ? are not confined to a unique reaction pathway; rather, pathways can be switched under perturbation. The theory allows one to identify the presence of multiple reaction pathways in a system?even when the pathways cannot be directly resolved in the experiment. 

An analytic theory was developed to describe the action-potential-triggered neurotransmitter release at the chemical synapse, the process that enables fast and precise communication between neurons. The theory is in detailed quantitative agreement with a vast array of experimental data, yielding testable predictions. A striking result of the theory is the established universality in the sensitivity of a synapse (peak transmitter release rate) to the trigger (calcium influx).

Broader Impacts. The developed theory of the infection by enveloped viruses established the physical principles that enable viruses to accelerate, by orders of magnitude, the otherwise prohibitively slow fusion with the cell membrane. Due to its general nature, the theory can be extended to other membrane-fusion-mediated processes, such as neuronal communication, fertilization, and development. 

The developed theory of conformational transitions in the presence of multiple reaction pathways addressed a hallmark of all biological systems ? their ability to tailor their function to a new environment. By showing how biological function can be tailored already at the single-molecule level, the theory is a step toward establishing the quantitative organizational laws that connect the molecular scale and biological function.

The developed theory of synaptic transmission provides the first analytically tractable framework for the principles underlying neuronal communication. As rapid and precise transmission of information through synapses is the key to our ability to feel, think, or act, the theory provides a basis for connecting, quantitatively, the molecular constituents of synapses to the computational and information-processing functions in the brain.

These developments built a foundation for extending single-molecule theory to the molecular behavior in vivo and to the larger scales of biological organization. This program provided training for junior scientists in developing physics-based conceptual approaches that can encompass the complexity of living systems and in becoming leaders in this multi-disciplinary field. These activities helped further expand the PI?s outreach initiatives to encourage and train scientists from a diverse range of academic and social backgrounds.
